articles.headline: Will Restart of Student Loan Payments Be the Last Straw for Consumers?
articles.snippet: Americans have continued spending despite dwindling savings and inflation. But retailers worry resuming loan payments could push some over the edge.
articles.abstract: Americans have continued spending despite dwindling savings and inflation. But retailers worry resuming loan payments could push some over the edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mykail James has a plan for when payments on her roughly $75,000 in student loans restart next month. She’ll cut back on her “fun budget” — money reserved for travel and concerts — and she expects to limit her holiday spending.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman, Jeanna Smialek and Jason Karaian

articles.headline: TikTok Rankles Employees With Return-to-Office Tracking Tools
articles.snippet: The company is requiring many employees to use an app that tracks their in-person attendance.
articles.abstract: The company is requiring many employees to use an app that tracks their in-person attendance.
articles.lead_paragraph: TikTok employees in the United States expressed frustration and dismay this week after the company introduced a tool for tracking office attendance and threatened disciplinary action for failing to comply with new in-person mandates, in an unusual effort to get workers back into the office with custom data-collection technology.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Emma Goldberg

articles.headline: After Brutal Attacks and Fierce Debate, U.K. to Ban ‘American Bully XL’ Dogs
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced steps to outlaw the dogs on Friday, after a string of deaths and a social media campaign piled pressure on the government to act.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced steps to outlaw the dogs on Friday, after a string of deaths and a social media campaign piled pressure on the government to act.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video, shot from a passing bus and lasting barely a minute, is harrowing. A powerful young dog bites an 11-year-old girl in front of a grocery store in Birmingham, England. As pedestrians scatter in terror, the dog chases a man into a gas station plaza, pulling him down repeatedly, its jaws clamped on the man’s arm and shoulder, as he tries desperately to shake off the animal.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler

articles.headline: U.A.W. Starts Strike Small, but Repercussions Could Prove Far-Reaching
articles.snippet: The union targeted three factories: one run by General Motors, one by Ford and one by Stellantis. Prolonged walkouts could hurt the U.S. economy and President Biden.
articles.abstract: The union targeted three factories: one run by General Motors, one by Ford and one by Stellantis. Prolonged walkouts could hurt the U.S. economy and President Biden.
articles.lead_paragraph: Autoworkers walked off the job on Friday at three factories that produce some of the Detroit carmakers’ most popular vehicles, the opening salvos in what could become a protracted strike that hurts the U.S. economy and has an impact on the 2024 presidential election.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: A Spirited Start to the Strike at a Ford Plant Near Detroit
articles.snippet: Union members at one of three factories chosen for a first wave of walkouts voiced determination to win substantial pay gains in their next contract.
articles.abstract: Union members at one of three factories chosen for a first wave of walkouts voiced determination to win substantial pay gains in their next contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rodney Cornett got up at 4:30 a.m. on Friday, hopped in his F-150 pickup and reported as usual for a morning shift at the Ford Motor plant in Wayne, a gritty city just west of Detroit.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Brittany Greeson

articles.headline: In Moscow, the War Is Background Noise, but Ever-Present
articles.snippet: Muscovites go about their daily lives with little major disruption. But the war’s effects are evident — in the stores, at the movies and in the increasingly repressive environment.
articles.abstract: Muscovites go about their daily lives with little major disruption. But the war’s effects are evident — in the stores, at the movies and in the increasingly repressive environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Metro trains are running smoothly in Moscow, as usual, but getting around the city center by car has become more complicated, and annoying, because anti-drone radar interferes with navigation apps.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: Dire Warnings About Libya Dams Went Unheeded
articles.snippet: “The state wasn’t interested,” said an engineer who published a paper on why Derna’s dams, after decades of postponed repairs, might fail under the stress of a powerful storm.
articles.abstract: “The state wasn’t interested,” said an engineer who published a paper on why Derna’s dams, after decades of postponed repairs, might fail under the stress of a powerful storm.
articles.lead_paragraph: It had been clear for years that the dams protecting Derna, on Libya’s Mediterranean coast, were in danger of giving way.
articles.byline: By Aaron Boxerman and James Glanz

articles.headline: Texas Attorney General Is Acquitted in Landmark Senate Trial
articles.snippet: Senators voted largely on party lines against conviction of the attorney general, Ken Paxton, who had been impeached on charges of corruption and abuse of office.
articles.abstract: Senators voted largely on party lines against conviction of the attorney general, Ken Paxton, who had been impeached on charges of corruption and abuse of office.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Texas Senate voted on Saturday to acquit the state’s attorney general, Ken Paxton, after a nine-day impeachment trial that focused on allegations of corruption and divided the Republican Party.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman, Edgar Sandoval and David Montgomery

articles.headline: In Risky Hunt for Secrets, U.S. and China Expand Global Spy Operations
articles.snippet: The nations are taking bold steps in the espionage shadow war to try to collect intelligence on leadership thinking and military capabilities.
articles.abstract: The nations are taking bold steps in the espionage shadow war to try to collect intelligence on leadership thinking and military capabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: As China’s spy balloon drifted across the continental United States in February, American intelligence agencies learned that President Xi Jinping of China had become enraged with senior Chinese military generals.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Edward Wong

articles.headline: How a Yale Student’s Rape Accusation Exposed Her to a Defamation Lawsuit
articles.snippet: The woman’s allegation led to the expulsion of Saifullah Khan, who was acquitted in a criminal trial. His lawsuit is now challenging these disciplinary hearings.
articles.abstract: The woman’s allegation led to the expulsion of Saifullah Khan, who was acquitted in a criminal trial. His lawsuit is now challenging these disciplinary hearings.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a 2018 disciplinary hearing at Yale University, Saifullah Khan listened as a woman accused him of raping her after a Halloween party.
articles.byline: By Vimal Patel

articles.headline: World’s Largest ‘Baby Exporter’ Confronts Its Painful Past
articles.snippet: South Korean adoptees have been returning to the country to hold the government accountable for what they call a corrupt adoption system that went largely unchanged until recent decades.
articles.abstract: South Korean adoptees have been returning to the country to hold the government accountable for what they call a corrupt adoption system that went largely unchanged until recent decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mia Lee Sorensen’s Danish parents used to tell her that her birth family in South Korea had put her up for adoption. According to her adoption papers, she was born prematurely in 1987 to a family that could not afford her medical bills and wished for her to have a “good future” abroad.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: This China Trade War Isn’t About Semiconductors
articles.snippet: Cosmetics sales in China are soaring, but a group of exporting nations led by France are pushing Beijing to lift restrictions they say are blocking them unfairly.
articles.abstract: Cosmetics sales in China are soaring, but a group of exporting nations led by France are pushing Beijing to lift restrictions they say are blocking them unfairly.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the gloom of China’s economy, one area of business is booming: cosmetics.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Elizabeth Paton

articles.headline: Behind Paxton’s Impeachment, a Republican Battle for Control of Texas
articles.snippet: The impeachment was the latest fight in an ongoing struggle between an emboldened hard right and the party’s more moderate old guard.
articles.abstract: The impeachment was the latest fight in an ongoing struggle between an emboldened hard right and the party’s more moderate old guard.
articles.lead_paragraph: The impeachment trial of Ken Paxton that ended in his acquittal on Saturday was about more than the fate of the Texas attorney general. It was also the most dramatic flashpoint in a yearslong struggle among Republican leaders in the Legislature over control of the party and the future direction of the state.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman

articles.headline: In Ukraine, a Rosh Hashana Party Not Even War Can Stop
articles.snippet: Every year, thousands of followers of Rebbe Nachman of Breslov descend on the town of Uman to worship, dance and pay homage at the tomb of their spiritual leader.
articles.abstract: Every year, thousands of followers of Rebbe Nachman of Breslov descend on the town of Uman to worship, dance and pay homage at the tomb of their spiritual leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yosef Chaim Bernfeld, a young businessman from New York who is trying to straighten out his life, journeyed to Uman this weekend for a “spiritual fix.”
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Daniel Berehulak

articles.headline: Some Businesses Make ‘Woke Free’ a Selling Point
articles.snippet: A number of companies — from clothing to pet care — are trying to appeal to customers who think corporate America is pushing a liberal agenda.
articles.abstract: A number of companies — from clothing to pet care — are trying to appeal to customers who think corporate America is pushing a liberal agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Isaac is a forward for the National Basketball Association’s Orlando Magic, but he is perhaps better known as someone who chose not to protest police brutality against Black Americans during a summer of widespread activism involving racial injustice.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar

articles.headline: ​Mark Meadows’s Testimony in Georgia Case May Have Done Him No Favors
articles.snippet: Mark Meadows, a former top Trump aide, took the witness stand in hopes of having his election interference case moved to federal court. So far, the strategy has not paid off.
articles.abstract: Mark Meadows, a former top Trump aide, took the witness stand in hopes of having his election interference case moved to federal court. So far, the strategy has not paid off.
articles.lead_paragraph: One morning last month in an Atlanta federal courtroom, Mark Meadows, former President Donald J. Trump’s final chief of staff, was in the hot seat. And he was the one who had put himself there.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: In U.S., Zelensky Will Make Case for More Aid, and Offer Thanks
articles.snippet: The Ukrainian leader’s second trip to America comes at a more delicate diplomatic moment, as he tries to navigate political currents while expressing gratitude for Western support.
articles.abstract: The Ukrainian leader’s second trip to America comes at a more delicate diplomatic moment, as he tries to navigate political currents while expressing gratitude for Western support.
articles.lead_paragraph: A hero’s welcome awaited President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on his first trip to the United States after Russia’s full-scale invasion, which came on the heels of two back-to-back military advances that showcased Ukrainian momentum to the West. Mr. Zelensky spoke to a joint session of Congress last December, highlighting the successes and appealing for continued aid.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: A Key Question in Google’s Trial: How Formidable Is Its Data Advantage?
articles.snippet: The government states that data is “oxygen for a search engine” and that Google’s anticompetitive behavior has given it a data fortress. Google says innovation explains its success.
articles.abstract: The government states that data is “oxygen for a search engine” and that Google’s anticompetitive behavior has given it a data fortress. Google says innovation explains its success.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government’s first monopoly trial of the modern internet era is less than a week old, but already a central character has emerged: data. Its role, its use and its power are key issues in the Justice Department’s case against Google.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Iran Releases 5 Americans as U.S. Unfreezes Billions in Oil Revenue for Tehran
articles.snippet: The terms of the deal have generated intense criticism from Republicans, even as the White House insists Iran will be prevented from spending the money on anything except humanitarian goods.
articles.abstract: The terms of the deal have generated intense criticism from Republicans, even as the White House insists Iran will be prevented from spending the money on anything except humanitarian goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five Americans who had been imprisoned in Iran were allowed to leave the country on Monday, President Biden said, after two years of high-stakes negotiations in which the United States agreed to unfreeze $6 billion in Iranian oil revenue and dismiss federal charges against five Iranians accused of violating U.S. sanctions.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Crisis and Bailout: The Tortuous Cycle Stalking Nations in Debt
articles.snippet: The government of Ghana is essentially bankrupt, and has turned to the International Monetary Fund for its 17th financial rescue since 1957.
articles.abstract: The government of Ghana is essentially bankrupt, and has turned to the International Monetary Fund for its 17th financial rescue since 1957.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emmanuel Cherry, the chief executive of an association of Ghanaian construction companies, sat in a cafe at the edge of Accra Children’s Park, near the derelict Ferris wheel and kiddie train, as he tallied up how much money government entities owe thousands of contractors.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen
